Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Many formalized, mathematical representations of musical meter. How to unpack a complex piece of music into its rhythmic elements.

Learned a theoretical framework for discussing musical meter, talked about various aspects including hypermeter, phrase structure, non-isochronous meter etc (all new terms to me). Very much a subjective, discussion based class, with hints of philosophy going on.

knowledge of metric systems; building a framework of meter that does not fall on the pitfalls of either 1) Westernized musical notation 2) ambiguous or unclear terminology; knowledge of anti-periodic and co-periodic relations, and an approach to music that lay in mathematical analysis and the beginnings of set theory. Knowledge of antimeter, non-isochronous meter, and other interesting facets of metric structure.
New method of describing musical meter, different types of musical meter, syncopations, hemiola, simultaneous meters
I learned an entirely new method of thinking about musical meter, and developed the tools to communicate effectively within that system.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Cohn is a brilliant professor, a musical wizard you can say. His writings are beautifully written. He is also a very kind person, and helps foster a warm musical community.

Weaknesses:

Awesome structure--topic very conducive to discussion. Loved being able to hear other students' views on a piece and understand different hearings of a song/track/piece. Amazing instructors, good discussion leading. Good classmates too! Assignments are quite open ended and allow you to present your own interpretation of pieces. Opportunity to present our own selections in class was also awesome!

Would love more focus on modern music! There was a healthy mix of it, but I do think the class was a little classical-heavy. I think it's the perfect class to engage with modern music theoretically.

Strengths: material laid out very clearly and effectively. Professor Cohn is an expert in this field, and so it was a wonderful opportunity to explore an aspect of music theory seldom taught in other courses. The course draws strongly on all types of music (not just classical), including rock, pop, vocal performance/opera, symphonic, and even Ghanaian drum patterns. The assignments require a significant amount of thought and writing but are very reasonable considering the time allowed. Grading was fair and reasonable, and always came back with helpful comments. Professor Cohn and Mr. Cox knew that mistakes regarding terminology would be frequent at the beginning of the semester --due to the fact that we are all still adapting to the new vernacular -- but were very understanding and helpful. These naturally decreased as the semester progressed. 

I appreciate the flexiblility with which both Professor Cohn and Mr. Cox approached due dates and material given the pandemic year.

Weaknesses: basically none. Despite being a new class, this class was expertly organized and very well structured, and Professor Cohn was very flexible. I see a few things on the initial syllabus that we didn't have time to fully explore -- perhaps the only thing would be if the earlier half of the course (building the framework of meter) went slightly faster so we had more time to explore those! This, however is a VERY MINOR weakness.

Strength: Great course for any student with musical interest, not too much background is required. You get to listen to lots of different types of music, not just classical music, but you get to see how musical patterns are present across multiple genres. 

Weakness: In person discussions could get convoluted if you didn't hear a certain pattern other people were hearing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Cohn is really thoughtful and considerate regarding the pandemic situations. He goes above and beyond to make sure students get the support they need.

I could not have been happier with the way the class approached the pandemic; while we did have a few technical issues along the way, Professor Cohn let the class explore the topics as a group, rather than sticking strictly to a very strongly defined schedule or syllabus. This allowed for a more dynamic experience where questions could be introduced and explored.

Sharing sound over Zoom was helpful since we could all listen to the same music at the same time, with high quality. As mentioned, I wish there was a better way we could coordinate our understandings and hearings of a piece of music, which is inherently difficult over Zoom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 100%. Prof. Cohn is fantastic. I am so lucky to have had him as my professor.

Yes, as long you find the difficulty of the material a good fit! Most discussions didn't require any kind of formal theory background, and after taking a few other 200/300 level music classes I didn't find the concepts too difficult to grasp. Even then, the ideas presented in this course are super interesting  Prof. Cohn doesn't flaunt it, but he's kind of a big deal in the theory world and published influential work on this very topic (although the class doesn't quite get far enough to reach his level of theory). On top of that, it certainly changed how I listen to all kinds of music (classical or otherwise) and I feel like I'm much more attentive to any interesting metric/rhythmic aspects of any piece. Prof. Cohn is an absolute joy to work with and is incredibly understanding about all of the difficulties that came up during covid I would highly recommend this (or any other course with him)!

yes. if you're new to music theory, take the plunge. I had no experience with the subject, but was attracted by the course number and description. I think it's a cool and unconventional way to get into music theory.

I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in studying an aspect of metric theory seldom taught in other courses; here is a great example of a Yale-style course, which explores new and exciting ideas of meter and its framework. The class is very well laid out, and I highly recommend you check out the "Strengths" section for the reasons why the class was a success.
Yes, if they have any musical interests, whether it be performance or just becoming a better listener.

As a music major, I would definitely recommend this course. You don't need to have experience performing or composing music, and even the ability to read standard Western music notation is not required. Take this course if you love music and you're curious about the inner workings of rhythm.
